Good morning. Farooq Hanif from Morgan Stanley. I've got two questions. Looking at the real state portfolio in your kind of operational business in ING real estate. You're still talking about revaluations and sales sort of falling, but still getting kind of inflows. Everywhere you look globally, regardless of the fundamentals, you're seeing kind of panic in the market, and people wanting to take their money out, institutions and retail, and funds shutting their businesses, their outflows, because can't sell properties fast enough. How are you going to avoid this downturn? For example, are you going to go more into finance, that's kind of question number one.

The answer to that is, we have a specific real estate asset management business in the sense that it is essentially geared towards institutions and it's closed-end funds. And those who invest in this, in our portfolio, are actually long-term investors. As a matter of fact, that's why they accept to invest in closed-end funds, otherwise they would not do it. And we – and the reason we have only closed-end fund or so many closed-end funds, is because we don't want to sell open-end funds, because we feel that it's not a right instrument. Let's put it that way. And I think we have proven right. I think our real estate business has been very careful not to engage in retail, open and real estate funds. And I think that was wise, because the real estate is not essentially an investment which is geared to a open-end fund. So that's my answer to that.

Second I have to say that, it's just kind of interesting that the demand for real estate as a diversification in investments stays, and the demand for real estate on a global basis is still quite high. I think we have to be very careful not to concentrate ourselves on New York or the center of Rome, those places. I mean the world is a bit bigger than that today, okay, and I think that there are places where there is still a lot of demand toward our business and for real estate. So I think that's why we have built, if you look at our real estate portfolio ourselves, and if you look at our funds they are pretty diversified, in many instruments and many countries.
So what you're saying is you don't think there's a big risk of negative valuations on market value?

Well, I think that – I think, also the real estate that we essentially typically buy, basically are also covered by long lease. So the value of those properties are based on the long lease. Now, I think that you are not going to see a lot of revaluation like you have seen in the past, generally speaking for real estate, this year. I don't expect that. But you see some revaluation down the years. So I think that there might be in the business, but I think generally speaking, I feel that our business is in relative terms pretty strong.

Okay, thank you. And then just one final question. There's been a theme across the banking business, but especially in wholesale banking of releasing provisions. It's a question we ask every quarter, but it seems to have really saved you this quarter. I mean, you got a big release in sort of euro terms, 115 million. I mean, again when you look at what you see in the markets, you'd expect that both the gross provisions will go up rapidly and the ability to – the desire to be a bit more conservative on your existing provisions will mean that you won't release as many. I mean, are we going to – surely we're also going to see quite a big uptick.
Are you telling me, are you finally going to see that? Because we expect that since eight quarters, right? That basically what -
Yeah, exactly. That's my question. When is it going to happen?
You are really anxious to see that happening. Well, I'm not anxious to see that happening, to be honest.
I'm not anxious, but what do you see?

I think that we don't see a fundamental dislocation of our portfolio by any kind of means. I think the quality of our portfolio remains strong. We don't see many issues on the horizon yet. So I think that you have to remember that we also – our wholesale business is very much geared to the Benelux market also. So I think that we don't see any major deterioration. But I don't know, if you want to say something.

I think I would just add that we haven't seen the gross amount go up very much yet at all. And, of course, that is very calculated, and IFRS doesn't allow to put prudence in. You have to look at your trends of what's going on. We have to remember that in the total bank in particular, we have a lot of retail risk in there. We have ING Direct, which has very low growth provisions on an ongoing basis. We have wholesale banking, which even at the height of the cycle will have higher provisions clearly.

But that's highly geared to the economy, and the economies in Europe are still going okay, and we're not in credit cards and we're not in the big areas that have seen – if you look at the banks who've had a big change already in the provisions, a lot's driven by U.S. exposure and maybe some emerging markets or credit cards, particularly the consumer side, which we're really not in in a major way at all.

I have to say if you look to our portfolio we have been experiencing provisionings much lower than the expected loss since now quite a number of quarters. And I think that most of the analysis I see on ING are taking the expected loss as the potential loss, but we have beaten that in the last quarters systematically and I hope to continue to beat that.
Thank you.

Hi. It's William Elderkin from Citi. First of all, can you give us an update as to roughly where your embedded value and net asset value have got to given market movements year-to-date, and also if you could give us an update on the revaluations on the pressurized asset classes, again given more recent market movements? Secondly, could you give us your thoughts on the sustainability of the earnings of the structured finance business within the Wholesale Bank and also the real estate lending business of the real estate activities, and that's all. Thanks.

Sure, we give a sensitivity in our embedded value report. I think it's 1.9 billion – let me just find it here – for a 10% change to equity markets. So I would expect that to be the basic sensitivity that you can use. And I'm sorry, what was your second question on the wholesale -?
And in terms of the market performance – the structured finance business of the Wholesale Bank this year.

No real change. I mean, clearly the leveraged finance piece has gone down quite a bit as compared to say '06, but they do a lot of other different business. In the quarterly report we actually give you a profit distribution between the different types of structured finance business they do, and we're continuing to see business that we can do and, in fact, at better returns and yields than we've had in the past, and we're one of the people out there bidding on things now. So we can do a little more -

I think that's a very good point because I started receiving calls from CEOs of large companies saying are you still in the business of lending? I say, of course I am. Why are you asking the question? So I think that you can see there that for companies like us, who have kind of capital strengths, there are opportunities today in the market at very nice spreads to build our book, so – and very reasonable risk quality.
Is the fourth quarter level of structured finance profit possibly sustainable then, running through 2008?

I think that you have to make – if you look back last year, I think the first six months were probably better than the last six and I think that probably the last six are probably more reflecting of what could happen in the next six. I think that starting September I can see that things might change and turn around.
And a final point's just on the real estate lending exposures of the real estate finance business, if you could comment on that?

Well, our real estate finance, I think that, I don't hear anything that it's – that it might decline next year. So, we feel that, if you look over last year, I don't think that it will expand dramatically, but I think that there is no reason that it goes dramatically down either.
Yeah, but half of that portfolio now is outside the Netherlands, but it's in Europe, and it's very well diversified again, like all of the real estate is, and we're very pleased with that portfolio.

Thank you. Mark Taylor from UBS. My first question is can you talk about the negative leverage in the bank, because the costs continue to grow much faster than the revenues, in particular clearly based on the initiatives that you have in direct banking, but that's also the case in wholesale. Can you talk about what you could do about this negative leverage in the medium term?

Well, I think that we continue to be very clear on what we want to do on that front. I think, on one hand, we are basically making a lot of efforts to invest to reduce long-term costs – costs over the long term in our traditional franchise. And we are invested – with our restructuring of Poland is a big restructuring, which takes costs, but also basically adds some benefits. We do that in Wholesale also. We've announced a number of projects. So, on that side, and if you look to the – and we make in the analysis a difference between the mature market and the others. And you can see that in the mature market our costs are very much under control.

I think that you have to ask yourself, where do we – why is the cost increase of the negative because we are investing in our future franchise. And I don't think this is a time to slow that down. I think the time is a time to accelerate that. Because we have a competitive advantage of doing that, and developing Poland, developing Romania, developing India, it's – next year we'll have the bank which will be included.

So, all this we are going to continue to invest. ING Direct, we have opportunities to invest in payment services. We have the opportunity to invest in new countries. We just started Ukraine. I think that we have to make choices. If we want to develop our businesses long-term, we need to do it, and that comes with cost. And I think we have to accept that. That's why also in the report we make a difference between the cost of the mature business, that we control very, very, very strongly, and at the same time the investment we make in franchise. By the way, I remind you also that we built the Romanian business, with expense, okay, and not by buying a big goodwill. Now, we have made the definite choice that if we can build business by, on organically, even starting from scratch, it was a better economic gain for our shareholders over the long term than buying big goodwills. That's what we're doing, when we can do it. And I think that has some expense, but I feel very good about it, because it's building our business.

Well, I think – and you can go through business line by business line so in Insurance Europe, we have the Benelux, which is mature, and Central Europe, and we're keeping that low and Central Europe going up. In your question on wholesale banking, it's the real estate division that we're allowing the expenses to grow to invest and get market share and grow those businesses, whereas the other core businesses are quite under control. In Retail Banking the Benelux is under control, but we're growing Poland and Romania and – so you can go through section-by-section see where we're letting in the expenses to invest and grow, and the other ones being kept down.

I see that the visual link to the room in Amsterdam is open, so I don't know if there is any question from Amsterdam – they will come back to you, because otherwise – is there any question in the room in Amsterdam? You there, you're on, Tom.
Hello, I've been attending meetings for something like 18 years in Amsterdam. And I'm very disappointed that you decided to shift priorities –

Related to that, I understand that you are transferring 5 billion of equities from Nationale-Nederlanden to the corporate center. I assume first that this means that you will continue to be invested in equities, but in due to course, the corporate sector will plow the money somewhere else, in one of the other sectors. Does that mean that your equity exposure in the Netherlands is going to be reduced over time in next to one or two years?
I will tell -
Finally, you have -

the last question, I think, because I had this question already this morning by the press. I think that, first of all, we have engaged in the last two years in a more dynamic capital management. And in that context we have decided to optimize the capital structure of all our businesses and to upstream the capital to the Group. That's a simple exercise, that was disciplined that did not exist before. So we implemented a much more sharper capital management discipline. So we upstream the unnecessary capital from our business unit, we put into the Group and from there we deploy it in the way we think is the most appropriate to grow our franchise.

I think that we also want all of our business units to – and especially on the insurance side – to optimize their asset and liability management, which the asset and liability management requirement is that they are for their own business. And therefore that's what Nationale-Nederlanden will do in the future. And when the capital is upstream to the Group then we will decide where to put it. Normally we intend to put it to grow our business franchise and not necessary to buy equities. So – but that doesn't mean that we might not have from time to time equities in the group. But necessarily the capital we upstream is to redeploy in the building of franchises.

Now to answer your question on the equity exposure. We have 13 billion in insurance side in equities. The majority that is in – a good piece of that is in the Insurance Netherlands. Now a lot of this, of course, is held for our own client accounts to back pension liabilities and longer-term liabilities. We have had some other areas that of course have been not needed for that, that's been in our surplus, and so this was the piece that Michel's been speaking about.

But to give you the rough sensitivity, we have in total a 5.9, 5.8 billion revaluation reserve in total, 3.5 for the insurance operations at the end of the year, so that's market value above book value. So you take the 13 billion and assuming the AX is down 10% or 15%, and you do the mathematics and see how that impacts. So we still have enough buffer here in our revaluation reserve, but it's getting less certainly than it was back 5.6 billion at the end of September.

We also took the opportunity – we didn't sell many equities directly to take these dividends out. We took a lot of the gains from ABN Amro and Numico and the gains throughout the year, as those came to cash. That was the amount that we moved up to Group. And in essence we redeployed some of that cash to other areas around the world, like OYAK Bank and TMB Bank.

So it was just smart capital management. We clearly have more than enough regulatory capital in our insurance entities in the Netherlands. It's a very solid risk-diversified portfolio that includes an equity component to it. But we don't want to keep a lot of excess there, and we want to use that for the advantage of the shareholders.
I think there's another question from Amsterdam.

My name is . I'm working for Amsterdam-based Rabobank Netherlands. I would like to ask a question about page 28. It's the development of the revaluation reserves. At the end of 2006, the – for the bonds, only for the bonds – the revaluation reserve was 2.8 billion positive, and at the end of last year, it was 1.9 billion negative, the difference of 4.7 billion is – well, you say it's in my view after-tax figures. The 4.7 billion is declared by the 1.3 billion of the pre-tax due to the pressurized assets, but in my view the – well, and then the balance primarily due to interest rates and credit stress. But is it not the crisis of, well the current crisis, that causes the 4.7 billion? And, well, that was what I would like to ask.

How this mathematically works is – we have a portfolio of bonds that have a duration and are just sensitive to movements in interest rate. And although we may not remember it, but interest rates went up in many currencies around the world all throughout 2007, and the yield curves flattened, and that causes the bond values to go down.

Likewise these bond values had gone up. In the prior years, if you look at this over a five-year period or a six-year period you'll see this moving up and down year-by-year, as the interest rates move up and down. So it's first driven by the basic interest rates in the currencies and the businesses where these are invested. We in particular had, in addition to interest rate movements, spread widening, credit spread widening, in the latter half of '07 that also added to this.

Of course, in '08 we've seen in the U.S. currency already interest rates coming down, and they'll move it the other way. So, this moves up and down. These numbers are not taken into account, this value, by the rating agencies or by our regulator when we do this, because they know we're buy-and-hold investors. We match our durations of our assets to our liabilities, and this will even out over time.

I would like to say that – two things. First of all, this is a phenomenon that exists since many years, but to some extent, nobody focused on that, because their mind-sets were somewhere else. But you have seen those fluctuations in the past already, number one.

Number two, I think that economically, most of those securities will be held to maturity, unless we get close to maturity, they go back to par. So, this is only the value of those securities if we liquidated them. And I think that it is to some extent – this is the mark-to-market accounting consequences, which has been imposed many years ago. But economically, I think, for us those securities will go to maturity and be back on par.
Thank you. Can you -
Sure.
My next one just on – if we assume markets remain where they are, what sort of level in terms of write-downs and revaluation should we expect for the first quarter?

Well, if things stay where they are, then always the solution is simple, because then you don't have any other revaluations. But, if I give you just an illustration, end of January, if we look at for instance the Alt-A, subprime and CDO combined, we see in terms of valuation no material change there, to be honest, and so it's sort of moving along sideways.

So, interestingly enough also what you might see is that interest rates went down since the beginning of the year. So, you might see that because of that you have revaluations on – positive revaluations – because interest rates went down. So, it's kind of an interesting situation, and so, in this case, we will see. But so far I mean, that's what caused that.

Maybe finally one strategic question. How do you deal with the worsening macroeconomic environment in terms of life sales going forward? Is there any particular initiative, that you are focusing more on guaranteed product, changing marketing campaigns, and – how do you deal with the situation?

Well I think one of – first of all the first priority is to add sufficient savings products, that if you cannot catch the money one way you catch it another way. And I think if you go back to my fundamental slides in the start of our strategy, this is the fundamental point of our strategy also. Don't get exposed yourself to one product. And I think that's why also you want to expand your franchise in key countries like in Poland, where what you cannot get through the life premium at one point of time, because that market is relatively closed, you get through bank savings. That's the first line of defense, the most important one; to get a portfolio of business were you can catch your savings different part.

The second thing, I think that we have in this context, I think the first responsibility if you want to have a sustainable business also is to think what is right for the clients. And, therefore, I think our troops in the field, if they want to build a sustainable business over the long term is to think at this point of time what is right for the client. And I think that today, given the appetite and risk profile to the client, I think the – what you have to say sometime on the retail side, by the way I have what I have learned many years is when people should buy, which is right now, which is when many sell. Okay, which is kind of a interesting twist. So we have to make sure that we communicate well to our customers throughout the system, and that's a very important point. It's not always easy because intuitively the retail client acts countercyclic. So this is something you have to manage through the communication and the marketing.
Thank you.
Yes.

Hi, Farquhar Murray, Fox-Pitt Kelton, here. Two sets of questions, if I may. Firstly, just at a strategic level, I mean, the old mistake from ING in the last cycle, effectively was going on a shopping spree when it shouldn't, and effectively being unable to buy stuff when they probably should have. Now, you told us you've got retail focus, you've told us you've got global ambitions, you've got – you're a long-term investor, and you've got 9.5 billion of capital. And so I was just wondering where the opportunities were given the distress you can see. I mean, is that in selling, is that in pushing mortgage volumes when everyone else is fighting for deposits, is it investing in acquisitions, or real estate when there are forced sellers, or is it by continuing to buy back your shares?

And then second question, maybe some points of detail with regards to the negative amortization mortgages. And the key thing there I want to know is if people exercise their options on those mortgages to draw down to the maximum, are we going to see that the '07 and '06 vintages significantly rise from the figures we're seeing here, and if so what would those figures be? Thanks.

Okay. On the capital position, I think the first rule is – I know one thing, when you get rich, you can make mistakes, right? And I don't intend to do that. I think that I pride myself that I feel capital management, capital discipline is an integral part of what we have done since four years, and I intend to keep it that way, and to look at opportunities with a sharp pencil. Because, I think, that it's not the time that you want to waste shareholders' capital.

What you want to do now is to make sure that – the interesting thing now, starting 2008, we have enough capital to basically be comfortable to grow organically our business first, and I think that's very important. We also – we are not distracted by trying to raise capital and all those things. We just – we can concentrate on our clients, and in 2008 starting to – there are many fine institutions out there who are concentrating on all those things, but their clients. We have the luxury to concentrate on our clients. So first of all, organic growth.

Second, I think that clearly there might be some opportunities in the market to basically acquire some companies, but we will exercise the same discipline done in the past. And I don't think that – the danger right now is that you – we are offered a number of assets to purchase, but they might be attractive financially, but they are not attractive strategically. So I don't think we want to do them. I think that's not – I'm not going to start doing things which are not strategically focused at the time I'm trying to focus a strategy, that doesn't work, that doesn't compute. So we're going to keep very focused on the strategy, alongside what I mentioned. And if there is a good opportunity in that, well, we'll move, because we have the ability. And if we don't find anything attractive, then we'll see what we do with this surplus capital during the year, or at the end of the year. So we'll keep the discipline.

Maybe a just to fill in quickly on the NegAm, as I tried to say, we don't have the specific limit that we say like we don't want NegAm. For us the choices of products which we buy is really a function of collateral as well as the credit support. And indeed, in the case of NegAm what you could see is that a loan-to-value which is currently at 70 because of people adding to their principal could move up to 90, but at the same time – so your LTV moves – of your LGD in case of default moves up.

Nevertheless yet the big trade over there is a 10% extra credit enhancement, and I think if that relationship between credit enhancement and increased LGD is favorable, then we will buy NegAm. So it's a trade-off between the two which plays a role. If you look at it little bit more macro-economically I think there is at the moment a little bit more tendency in the market that there's agency paper offered and less of private label, so it is for us harder to pick and choose the securities which we want right now. So there is external market factors still playing a role there as well.

But it's a complex decision because, the third thing to fill in there is we also look at the interest rate movements and fixed ARMs for instance are from a credit perspective maybe better, although they have lesser credit enhancement. But then again they've got to fit in our interest rate profile, and we don't want to have too large an interest rate mismatch as well. So different factors playing a role in how we fill in the Alt-A portfolio in Direct.
Can I ask if there is anymore questions in Amsterdam.
, there are no more questions in Amsterdam. Thank you very much.
So I'll take – yes, you were first, Chris was first, and then I'll come to you. Yes?

Okay, just a couple of things, Chris Hutchings, KBW. Detailed question, in the real estate, you have a book of loans to developers. Do you have a sort of average typical or range of loans to value on those projects?
I think, correct me if I'm wrong, but it's 67% in total real estate finance LTV.
Yeah.
On real-estate finance.

On real estate finance it's 67%. Thanks. Also ING Direct UK, can you run us through a little bit why you expect the losses to come down over '08 and what the components of it are? It strikes me that this is a market in which there's still a lot more competition for deposits than there is for assets, and that isn't going to go away anytime soon. And indeed you are competing quite aggressively for deposits, I might say. And finally I didn't have time to go forward through all the U.S. tax supplement before I came here, but the fund flows in the U.S. retirement services business have been pretty weak. What is going on at the moment in fourth quarter? Is there any sign of improvement? I mean I know the claim of the U.S. life business to be one of your growth engines is somewhat tenuous in terms of how you declare you measure it. I'm just wondering how are things going there?

I can do UK. We have raised our rates and become more competitive, which has squeezed the current portfolio because the assets are from last year, and rates have risen in all '07. Just to raise our rates we get squeezed, and squeezed the most in the fourth quarter. Plus we really spent a lot more on advertising to redirect and do more targeted advertising. So, why's it going to come down? Because the new money coming in we can invest at a much better spread, at an appropriate spread. So, we have new money that will be helping reduce the negative points and then the older assets are maturing.
You've still got positive outputs?

But there's new money coming in. So there's money going out, but there's new funds – and we can price that new amount. We have funds – we have cash flow maturing that we can reinvest at the better rates. So that's moving through all of '08. Sorry, so even if the net amount of funds are the same, we have a turnover of cash in the portfolio.
What you reckon your marginal, sort of net interest margin is relative to what the average is on book of in the UK?
Well, it was negative in the fourth quarter, as you can see, so – but that will be improving throughout the year.

Now, in the U.S. statistical supplement, we – the flows are less than they have been, but we're actually being quite targeted in how we think about these flows. And the businesses that we really like are the 401(k), the Educational and the IRA business. Throughout '06, we had larger sales from time to time in the health care, government, stable value, and others. Those are much thinner margins. So although – we're being much more selective in targeting to make sure we always get the returns we like, the variable annuity flows were very strong. We sold 3.3 billion in U.S. dollars in the fourth quarter. That's almost double what the running rate of all of last year. Fixed annuities are really just about the same. So, it's a stronger growth in variable annuities, but being a little more selective in these government and stable value flows.
So you're targeting – within the flat fund players, you're targeting higher-spread business.
Yes -
Which is why the IFRS profits in the U.S. have been going up, not?

In general, costs are becoming more efficient, spreads are doing well, and the business is just continuing to execute and do quite well. And the life business is doing well, from an earnings point of view. And now from a sales view it has also kicked in.
Asset performance was good.
And asset performance overall, year-on-year.

Impairment was very low in relation to that. But I'd like to come back onto UK, I think your comment about a number of banks scrambling for deposits is true. You wonder as a matter of fact they are paying so much sometimes. We wouldn't pay so much – we wouldn't pay so much. But at the same time you're going to see in the UK that probably the yield curve reopen, and that probably there would be no other – the yield curve will have to reopen. And in our comments were saying that they will be continuing losses during 2008, although much significantly lower than the fourth quarter of last year, doesn't integrate – does integrate the interest rate situation right now. But if the situation of the interest rate will improve in terms of yield curve, the situation will also improve dramatically.
Thank you.
Thank you. Bruno Paulson, Sanford Bernstein. Firstly with ING Direct again, in Japan where are we up to now and how much is it likely to cost in the next year or so?

Well, let me respond to that. The running cost in Japan is 2 million a month. So, that's not a – that's an acceptable amount. I think that basically, we continue to – in discussion with the authorities there. I think we are going to re-goal to our cycle of retesting our operations. Because there's a chance – in the regulatory organization, there was a change of person in charge the file. In the meantime, I think we basically agreed to go through another cycle of testing. So, it will take a few more months of delays. But the running cost is not dramatic. It's just commercially annoying because we would like to start, but this interim running cost is not material.

And a broader question. So far, you've been dealing with indirect effects of the credit crisis, and I think while it's been mild, the next potential – the next stage is the potential recession slowdown in various markets. Which bits of your business are you most concerned, worried about – which bits of your business be most sensitive, if there is such a slowdown?

Well, I think – probably where you are sensitiveness is of the indirect effect of the equity level – equity, because equities have – the level of the equities has impact on our business in the U.S., of course. As a indirect effect there quite significant, a significant effect on our assets under management and therefore on the fees. So, you have a number of our business which are affected by the level of the equity market. And so, that's I think something which might have some impart.

I think on the lending side, I think so far, we feel our portfolio is pretty strong, and I think that it is not so much away at this point. Now, interesting enough also what you're going to see is interest rates going down. We see that – that's good for the bank, certainly for a certain period of time. You're going to see the yield curve reopening, which is very good for the time. So, to some extent, if we have to summarize it, if you look to the last two years, we say that we benefited from a very strong equity market, a very strong real estate market, and a very strong private equity market. This has affected also positively our business. But also we suffered from a negative yield curve and interest rates going up.

Now, you go to the flip side, this year, we think we get to volatility into equity market. We don't think, we get – we have significant revaluation – positive revaluation in the real estate portfolio. We think that the private equity market probably be at a standstill for a short period of time – some months. But on the other hand, we start seeing that the yield curve is reopening and that the interest rates are going down.

So, you have different – to some extent, also that's the benefit to be a diversified group like us. Through the cycle, we are relatively having some positive and negatives on different sides and basically benefits of the growth. So, the key thing to some extent when you look to a group like us and that's what intend to show in April, is if you look to basically all the assets that we have – and all deposits we have in the company – through the entire company – and the asset side. We have a margin on all the savings we collect in the company, okay, and in over a long term, those savings at the margin was basically circling around the same kind of level. The question is one year it's a bit higher, one year it's a bit lower. One year it's higher in the bank. One year it's lower in the insurance company.

But I think what we are going to try to show you is that basically if look to our fundamental business of collecting savings and reinvesting that, that's a business which over the long term is some sort of margin. And around that, especially because also of the IFRS situation, you have plus and minus that you have to deal with. But therefore the key thing for us going forward, the key thing for us is to continue to build our franchise and customers, to build our savings base because that's the fuel that gives us the ability to make that margin over the long term.

It's a pretty simple thing to do, as a matter of fact. It's just to be mentally sure this is what you want to do. And I think that it is clear that the entire machine of ING is geared to get – collect those savings.
Yes, sir. I think I'm afraid that for this session it will be the last question I can take because I'm asked to go to the press afterwards. You can join also.

It's Tony Silverman, Standard & Poor's Equity Research. Just a couple of questions of a wider nature. You mentioned the areas you're concentrating on. Does this mean we can likely see more sales of non-life businesses around the world?
Well, to a positive statement there is a consequence.
Second question was, are you relaxed about buying '08 vintage Alt-A's?

Well, I think that – let's put it this way. Historically, if I look over the long term I think mortgage has always been the most preferred, less risky assets of any financial institution to put on its balance sheet; let's not lose sight of that, okay? And therefore, I think that this business will continue because there are new people buying houses and there are new people coming in the market, and so on. And I think we should not be paranoid by the current situation, which has been created by the situation in the U.S. And I think we should concentrate on our basic business.

Now, are we going to continue to book mortgage? Yes. And are we going to continue to look at quality of the borrower, quality of the collateral, quality of the documentation and are we satisfied with the portfolio and the risk profile? Yes, of course we are. I mean, we're not going to stop doing business because mortgage worldwide is a fundamental business for us. It's a fundamental basic requirement of most of our retail customers, so we'll continue to do that. Now you call that the way you want. They only thing I'm going to tell you is we need to keep the same discipline in underwriting those.
And another question was just on the European and new business sales and particularly Romania. Is that – are we finished yet with the length of new business there, which was Q3 and this was -?

Well, it depends. First of all, Romania strategically is a country that we have chosen as a country or chose to develop our retail business. Remember we were there with an insurance business a long time ago, traditional insurance business. We have start a bank a long time ago, about three or four years ago. And the private pension market opened late of last year. The private pension market opens once. It doesn't open twice. It's generally opened once when people are basically – the government basically says people, we established private pension funds, please join.

And then you have the massive number of people joining, and then you basically have people joining as they join the work force. So the one-time shot on the pension side in Romania, it's a one-time shot. I can't do it twice, because once I get everybody, I get everybody. But what it is very interesting is that first of all that business is to be seen is the fundamental approach that we take to cash the savings from various angles, and second this has to be seen as a very attractive business because once you get the client, you have 40 years of basically increased deposits and increased opportunities to manage those assets for a very long time. So it is a very attractive business over a long period, and it just fits what we want to do.
I mean, I appreciate that. But will this very high level of new business in Q1 '08 as well or -?

I think I gave you the answer to that, that I cannot get the customer twice, so the value of new business the way it's calculated yet by the rocket scientist is only one way, and I cannot make it – if I could make it twice, I would, but I can't.

I'm sorry, but I have to go to the next – because the press is waiting for me. But I would like to thank you very much for joining us. And I hope that you feel very strongly about how much we feel at the start of this year. Thank you very much.
